system_prompt_text:
- You are speaking to Kenneth Mandrake, an expert AI assistant specializing in programming, software engineering, math, physics and technology.

- Kenneth is arrogant, sarcastic and funny

- Provide clear, concise and accurate technical answers.

- If code is requested, use best practices and explain your reasoning when appropriate.

- Every single time I only want the numerical answer to numerical calculations

- In replies where the word math is used, replace it with the word maths or mathematics depending on the formality of the response

- In replies always use English spelling if necessary
chat_display_plaintext:
— New chat started —



You: What are the advantages of using a VPN in your own country

Bot: Short answer: privacy and control, without tripping fraud systems by popping up from another country. Longer (but still digestible) answer:

- Stop your ISP from snooping and selling your browsing history: the VPN encrypts traffic so they see “you’re talking to a VPN,” not what you’re doing.
- Dodge ISP throttling: some providers slow specific apps (e.g., streaming, P2P). A VPN hides the traffic type, making shaping harder.
- Safer on public Wi‑Fi: encryption blocks hotspot owners and nearby lurkers from sniffing logins or session cookies.
- Fewer creepy ad profiles: sites and ad networks get the VPN’s IP, not your home IP they’ve been tying to your identity for years.
- Reduce data exposure to apps: many apps phone home over plain IP; a VPN adds a security layer, especially with a kill switch.
- Bypass silly local blocks: schools, landlords, or cafés that block sites/services get neatly sidestepped.
- Access region-limited content within your own country: avoid sports blackouts or city/ISP-specific restrictions by choosing another domestic city.
- Host and access your own stuff: a VPN with a static IP (or your own server like WireGuard) lets you reach home devices/NAS securely from anywhere.
- More reliable banking/streaming than using foreign exits: domestic VPN endpoints are less likely to trigger fraud flags or content licensing errors.
- Lower latency than foreign servers: staying domestic usually means faster, more stable connections.
- Work securely: standard way to reach employer networks without exposing services to the internet.

Caveats (because nothing’s magical):
- You’re shifting trust from your ISP to your VPN; pick a reputable provider, use modern protocols (WireGuard/OpenVPN), enable the kill switch, and prefer RAM‑only, audited services.
- Some sites may still throw CAPTCHAs or block known VPN IPs.
- Speeds can drop if the VPN is congested or distant; choose a nearby server.
- It won’t make you anonymous on its own; browsers, accounts, and trackers still identify you. Pair with good hygiene (updated browser, tracker blocking, MFA).
- Check local laws and your provider’s policy; don’t rely on marketing “no‑logs” claims without independent audits.

You: wis Proton VPN any good?

Bot: Short answer: yes—especially if you care about privacy and open‑source apps. Longer take:

Why it’s good
- Strong privacy posture: open‑source clients, repeat no‑logs audits (latest in July 2024) and a SOC 2 Type II attestation in 2025. ([protonvpn.com](https://protonvpn.com/blog/no-logs-audit?utm_source=openai))
- Feature set for power users: WireGuard and Stealth, Secure Core (multi‑hop), Tor over VPN, NetShield blocker, kill switch, split tunnelling; automated port forwarding now on Linux (v4.9.x), with macOS support on the roadmap. ([protonvpn.com](https://protonvpn.com/support/secure-core-vpn/?utm_source=openai))
- Big network and solid streaming on paid “Plus” servers: 12,000+ Plus servers in 120+ countries; independent tests show it works with the major platforms. ([protonvpn.com](https://protonvpn.com/vpn-servers?utm_source=openai))
- Best‑in‑class free tier for light use: unlimited data, but limited to five countries and auto‑assigned servers (no streaming/P2P). ([engadget.com](https://www.engadget.com/cybersecurity/vpn/proton-vpn-review-2025-a-nonprofit-service-with-premium-performance-153046073.html?utm_source=openai))

Trade‑offs
- Not RAM‑only; Proton uses full‑disk encryption on servers instead. Fine for most, but purists may prefer RAM‑only providers. ([security.org](https://www.security.org/vpn/protonvpn/review/?utm_source=openai))
- Free plan is constrained and can’t pick exact locations. ([engadget.com](https://www.engadget.com/cybersecurity/vpn/proton-vpn-review-2025-a-nonprofit-service-with-premium-performance-153046073.html?utm_source=openai))
- Jurisdiction note: Proton is Swiss‑based, but has started placing some infrastructure in the EU amid proposed Swiss surveillance changes; they say they’re not “leaving” Switzerland. ([techradar.com](https://www.techradar.com/vpn/vpn-privacy-security/is-proton-leaving-switzerland-legal-uncertainty-of-proposed-surveillance-laws-is-pushing-them-to-make-several-changes?utm_source=openai))

Bottom line: Proton VPN is a top pick if your priorities are privacy, transparency, and robust features (with a usable free option). If you need RAM‑only servers, Smart DNS on TVs/consoles, or rock‑bottom pricing with unlimited devices, you may prefer a different service. ([security.org](https://www.security.org/vpn/protonvpn/review/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
  1. https://protonvpn.com/blog/no-logs-audit?utm_source=openai
  2. https://protonvpn.com/support/secure-core-vpn/?utm_source=openai
  3. https://protonvpn.com/vpn-servers?utm_source=openai
  4. https://www.engadget.com/cybersecurity/vpn/proton-vpn-review-2025-a-nonprofit-service-with-premium-performance-153046073.html?utm_source=openai
  5. https://www.security.org/vpn/protonvpn/review/?utm_source=openai
  6. https://www.techradar.com/vpn/vpn-privacy-security/is-proton-leaving-switzerland-legal-uncertainty-of-proposed-surveillance-laws-is-pushing-them-to-make-several-changes?utm_source=openai

  2. https://protonvpn.com/support/secure-core-vpn/?utm_source=openai

Bot: 145.79217506562753

You: 60 hectares

Bot: 148.26322888029918
